author: By Annie Correal and Julie Turkewitz
title: 170 Migrants Deported From U.S. Agree to Return to Home Countries, Panama Says
description: Days after the United States sent 300 migrants from Asia and the Middle East to Panama, a Panamanian official said that more than half had agreed to be deported to their countries of origin.
content: Nearly a week after the United States sent roughly 300 migrants from around the world to Panama on military deportation flights, officials in Panama said on Tuesday that more than 170 had agreed to be deported to their countries of origin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Anne Marie Hochhalter, Paralyzed in Columbine Shooting, Dies at 43
description: Fiercely independent, she publicly discussed the long-term effects of gun violence and spoke of forgiveness.
content: Anne Marie Hochhalter, who spoke publicly about the long-lasting effects of gun violence after she was paralyzed in the 1999 mass shooting at Columbine High School in Colorado, was found dead on Sunday at her home in Westminster, Colo. She was 43.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: They’ve Been Waiting Years to Go Public. They’re Still Waiting.
description: Some tech companies are delaying or pulling their listing plans as the Trump administration’s tariff announcements and other changes cause market volatility and uncertainty.
content: Turo, a car rental start-up in San Francisco, has been trying to go public since 2021. But a volatile stock market in early 2022 delayed its listing. Since then, the company has waited for the right moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A.’s Food Safety Chief Resigns Over Trump Administration Layoffs
description: The chief said the loss of critical employees overseeing the nation’s food supply made his work impossible. Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the nation’s new health secretary, has pledged to gut the division.
content: Jim Jones, the director of the Food and Drug Administration’s food division, resigned on Monday, citing what he called “indiscriminate” layoffs that would make it “fruitless for him to continue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Trump Cuts Target Next Generation of Scientists and Public Health Leaders
description: A core group of so-called disease detectives, who track outbreaks, was apparently spared. But other young researchers are out of jobs.
content: The notices came all weekend, landing in the inboxes of federal scientists, doctors and public health professionals: Your work is no longer needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Costa Rica Will Take Central Asian and Indian Migrants Deported by U.S.
description: Costa Rica is the second Central American nation to accept migrants from distant countries as the Trump administration ramps up deportation flights.
content: Costa Rica announced on Monday that it would receive a flight this week from the United States carrying 200 migrants from Central Asia and India, making it the second nation in Central America to accept deportees from faraway countries who had crossed illegally into the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Agrawal
title: Heart Failure Deaths Are Increasing. New Treatments Could Help.
description: New drugs and a growing awareness of the common condition offer hope for patients.
content: Ann Ramirez first noticed something was wrong when, at age 48, she started waking up in the middle of the night out of breath. It felt like she was underwater, and had to wait for a wave to pass to come up for air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Madison Malone Kircher
title: California Bill Seeks Age Minimum on Anti-Aging Skin Care Products
description: Revamped legislation would require anyone purchasing the products to provide proof that they are 18 or older.
content: In February of last year, as videos of tweens racing to Sephora for beautifully packaged creams and serums that contained anti-aging chemicals flooded TikTok, a legislator in California tried to end that trend by introducing a bill that would stop stores from selling those products to them. It failed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan, Glenn Thrush and Adam Goldman
title: Prosecutor in U.S. Attorney’s Office in Washington Abruptly Resigns
description: The resignation of the prosecutor, Denise Cheung, comes at a turbulent moment at the Justice Department, as President Trump and his appointees seek to exert control over law enforcement actions.
content: A top federal prosecutor in Washington, D.C., abruptly resigned on Tuesday after she declined a request from Trump administration officials to freeze assets of a government contractor, saying she had insufficient evidence to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Maher Knocks Trump’s Gutting of the Federal Work Force
description: “America is in shock that the guy whose catchphrase was ‘You’re fired’ is firing everybody in government,” Bill Maher said of President Trump on “Real Time.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Zachary Small
title: Art Adviser. Friend. Thief.
description: Lisa Schiff became the country’s leading art consultant, and drew her clients close. Then she stole millions from them. Now facing up to 20 years in prison, is she ready to repent?
content: Lisa Schiff sat at her kitchen table, trying to explain how she went from being one of the world’s most celebrated art advisers to a high-society pariah and a felon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Maria Abi-Habib, Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
title: C.I.A. Expands Secret Drone Flights Over Mexico
description: The covert program, begun during the Biden administration and stepped up by President Trump, is hunting for the location of fentanyl labs.
content: The United States has stepped up secret drone flights over Mexico to hunt for fentanyl labs, part of the Trump administration’s more aggressive campaign against drug cartels, according to U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia Frees American Prisoner Before Talks With U.S.
description: The release of Kalob Byers Wayne, who was arrested on drug charges on Feb. 7, came on the eve of talks about the war in Ukraine.
content: Russia released another American held on drug charges on Monday, in what the Kremlin acknowledged was a good-will gesture on the eve of talks between senior Russian and U.S. officials in Saudi Arabia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Gelinas
title: Pay Attention to the Words Elon Musk Uses With DOGE
description: Elon Musk’s team has only the powers that Congress gives it, or doesn’t give it — explicitly or implicitly, actively or passively.
content: It’s important to pay attention to the language of Elon Musk’s “Department of Government Efficiency,” and notice that three of the four words in the name are purposeful illusions. DOGE is not a department, and it is not focused on government efficiency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Isabel Kershner
title: Two Tiny Captives, Symbols of Hostage Crisis, to Go Home Dead, Hamas Says
description: Hamas said it would turn over the bodies of the boys, Ariel Bibas and his baby brother, Kfir, and their mother. Israel was expected to release Palestinian prisoners in exchange.
content: For more than a year, many Israelis and others around the world have anguished over the fates of a mother and her two young sons who were captured by gunmen and taken to Gaza during the Hamas-led assault of Oct. 7, 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Benjamin Oreskes and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Hochul Holds Meetings on Mayor’s Future, Plunging Him Deeper Into Crisis
description: With four key deputy mayors saying they planned to step down, Mayor Eric Adams is facing growing questions about his ability to lead New York City.
content: On the 39th floor of a Midtown Manhattan high-rise, Gov. Kathy Hochul on Tuesday presided over a series of meetings to discuss one of the most consequential decisions of her tenure: whether to remove Mayor Eric Adams from office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Christina Jewett
title: Kennedy Says ‘Nothing’ Off Limits in Scrutinizing Chronic Disease
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., laying out his early health agenda, said he would examine childhood vaccines, psychiatric drugs and other “formerly taboo” topics in investigating the causes of chronic disease.
content: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., in his first address to employees of the Department of Health and Human Services, said a new presidential commission would scrutinize childhood vaccine schedules, psychiatric medications and other frequent targets of his suspicion as part of his efforts to fight chronic disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
title: A Displaced Father Was Desperate to Return Home. He Never Made It.
description: Thousands uprooted by the war in Lebanon have been unable to reach southern towns occupied by Israel, but some have tried anyway. For one man, the journey was deadly.
content: For months after the Israel-Hezbollah war that devastated southern Lebanon, the Alawieh family would visit a hillside near their ruined home to catch whatever glimpse they could of what remained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Lange
title: Dylan Mulvaney Dreams of Privacy. Really.
description: Her bubbly video diaries about her gender transition were once a study in oversharing. Now on the other side of a nationwide boycott, she sees the value in keeping some things to herself.
content: It was early February, and Dylan Mulvaney was floating on the high seas — somewhere in the Caribbean, perhaps near St. Martin — on a cruise ship filled with nearly 5,000 gay men. Ms. Mulvaney, the 28-year-old performer, trans video diarist and cultural lightning rod at the center of an infamous Bud Light boycott in 2023, reported with a bright voice and wide smile that she was one of about “three women total” on the ship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Linares
title: 10 Ways to Turn Store-Bought Rotisserie Chicken Into a Healthy Dinner
description: Last night, a hot bird saved my life.
content: If you’re reading this, it may already be too late: The day’s done, you’re zapped. Why not put a bird on it — that is, a char-kissed, ready-to-eat rotisserie chicken? Put your trust in this staple, and you can have spring salads, sandwiches, soups and suppers that are easy, delicious and even healthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Vance’s Munich Disgrace
description: The vice president’s speech was a monument of arrogance based on a foundation of hypocrisy.
content: In April 1928, Joseph Goebbels, later the Third Reich’s chief propagandist, wrote a newspaper essay addressing the question of why the National Socialists, despite being an “anti-parliamentarian party,” would nonetheless compete in that May’s parliamentary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai, Ian Austen, Niraj Chokshi and Yan Zhuang
title: A Passenger Jet Flips and Burns, but This Time Tragedy Is Averted
description: All 80 people aboard Delta Flight 4819 survived a crash landing at a windy and snowy Toronto airport.
content: A day after a jetliner flipped moments after landing in Toronto, what was left of the aircraft remained upside down on Tuesday, its right wing and tail sheared off and the wreckage blocking the two longest runways at Canada’s busiest airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Cold and Flu Season
description: How do you take care of yourself when you’re sick?
content: Have you or the people around you been sick more than usual lately?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Best Interests’ Is a Deeply Empathetic British Series
description: Starring Sharon Horgan and Michael Sheen, the four-part series, on Acorn TV, is a heartbreaking look at two parents in an impossible situation.
content: There are no villains in “Best Interests,” a heartbreaking limited series that arrives on Acorn TV on Monday. Instead, the series, a four-part British drama starring Sharon Horgan and Michael Sheen, is about two people in impossible circumstances who are trying to do what they think is right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Florida Man Blames Mental Health Crisis for Shooting of Israeli Tourists
description: The gunman, who is Jewish, told the police that he thought the tourists were Palestinian.
content: A man in Florida charged with attempted murder in the shooting of two tourists in Miami Beach on Saturday — he told the police he had thought they were Palestinian — is attributing the violence to a “severe” mental health episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Nike Bets Big on Kim Kardashian
description: The Skims founder will enter into a rare business deal with the sports apparel company.
content: More than 40 years ago, Michael Jordan helped Nike become the name in basketball sneakers. Today it’s betting that Kim Kardashian can help it do the same for women’s activewear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: 5 Factors That May Shape Hochul’s Decision on Adams’s Fate
description: Amid increasing calls to remove Mayor Eric Adams from office, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York is weighing a complicated set of considerations.
content: There is little doubt, as far as the New York State Constitution is concerned, that Gov. Kathy Hochul has the power to remove Mayor Eric Adams of New York City from office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
title: Elon Musk Zeroes In on the I.R.S.
description: The tech mogul’s cost-cutting initiative is seeking sensitive taxpayer data, drawing concerns about privacy, potential political retribution and more.
content: The fire hose of Elon Musk news continues: We’ve got more on the controversy over the access to sensitive I.R.S. data that Musk’s cost-cutting team is seeking and the resignation of a senior official at the Social Security Administration over a similar issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: Trump’s Cuts Could Make Parks and Forests More Dangerous, Employees Say
description: Thousands of employees who helped oversee vast areas of wilderness have lost their jobs in President Trump’s moves to shrink the federal work force.
content: Public lands in the United States have long been considered a national treasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar
title: Arctic Air Mass Brings Dangerous Temperatures to Parts of the U.S.
description: And a winter storm could dump up to a foot of snow from the Central Plains to the East Coast.
content: A powerful surge of arctic air from Canada descended on the Central and Eastern United States this week, delivering record-breaking cold and life-threatening low wind chills even to regions accustomed to frigid temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley, D'Angelo Lovell Williams and Milton David Dixon III
title: The Women Who Are Reinventing R&B
description: A group of young singer-songwriters have transformed the genre by looking backward, without getting stuck in the past.
content: THE R&B SINGER-SONGWRITER Muni Long has a voice that people say could sing the dictionary and they’d still listen. In 2007, as a teen growing up in Gifford, Fla., she put that claim to the test, recording a five-minute YouTube clip in which she sings from Webster’s II New Riverside Dictionary (“aardvark, aardwolf, Aaron …”) to the tune of Fergie’s “Glamorous” (2006). That playful stunt, along with a handful of covers, caught the attention of Capitol Records. Under her given name, Priscilla Renea, she recorded her 2009 debut, “Jukebox,” an album of pop originals that earned good reviews but modest sales. By her 22nd birthday, she no longer had a record deal. Reinventing herself as a songwriter, she spent the next decade building a chameleonic career, writing the 2013 global hit “Timber” for Pitbull and Kesha, as well as songs for Miranda Lambert, Rihanna, Madonna, Sabrina Carpenter and dozens of others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: U.S. and Russia Pursue Closer Ties
description: Also, Mayor Eric Adams faces political peril. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: President Trump sent a high-level delegation to Saudi Arabia to meet with senior Russian officials today and discuss a plan to end the war in Ukraine. After four hours of negotiations — the most extensive in years between the two powers — participants in the meeting suggested that the U.S. and Russia would begin to work more closely together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Federal Judge Declines to Block Musk’s Team From Having Access to Education Data
description: The ruling said that the students who sued had failed to show that sensitive information had been illegally disseminated in a way that would justify an emergency restraining order.
content: A Federal District Court judge in Washington declined to bar associates of Elon Musk from gaining access to the Education Department’s data systems, finding that the University of California Student Association, which sued to block the incursion, had not shown that students were irreparably harmed in the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: South Africa Is a Warning
description: By closing their frontiers to migrants, rich countries risk destabilizing important nations across the globe.
content: This essay is part of The Great Migration, a series by Lydia Polgreen exploring how people are moving around the world today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Why Trump’s Bullying Is Going to Backfire
description: The scariest thing about what President Trump is doing with his tariffs-for-all strategy is that he has no clue what he is doing.
content: — “Revolution 1,” the Beatles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 619
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Feb. 19, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maxim Loskutoff
title: What Does the Future Hold for These 3 Friends, and for the Nation?
description: Set in a rapidly warming Montana valley, a new novel spans 50 years of a rocky friendship.
content: Even if you live in Montana, the place is partly a dream — a fantasy shaped by our cultural imagination and the vestiges of frontier mythology. But our vision of its future, and that of the rest of America, is now filtered through the dystopian lens of climate fear and grief. Eric Puchner wrestles with these competing images in “Dream State,” a multigenerational saga set in a fictionalized version of Montana’s Flathead Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz, Hamed Aleaziz, Farnaz Fassihi, Annie Correal and Federico Rios
title: As Trump ‘Exports’ Deportees, Hundreds Are Trapped in Panama Hotel
description: The administration has asked Panama to take in hundreds of people who can’t easily be sent back to their countries. Many say they are in danger.
content: They arrived at the United States border from around the world, hoping to seek asylum. Instead, they were detained, shackled and flown by the U.S. military to a faraway country, Panama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: Jonathan Bailey’s Bratty, Bad-Boy ‘Richard II’
description: The actor, on a hot streak after “Wicked,” takes on his biggest stage role to date. In London, he plays Shakespeare’s unfortunate king as a flouncing sociopath.
content: The Bridge Theater is within walking distance of the Tower of London, where in 1399 King Richard II was imprisoned and forced to abdicate England’s throne in favor of his cousin, who became Henry IV. Where better to stage a new production of William Shakespeare’s play about Richard’s downfall? From the playhouse foyer, theatergoers can look out at the tower across the River Thames, and the distance of those 600 years shrinks to nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Chris Cameron
title: Firings Expand at Interior Department With Purge of Probationary Workers
description: More than 2,000 workers at the Interior Department were fired in recent days, according to counts from workers groups and those familiar with the cuts, as probationary workers were targeted across the government.
content: The Trump administration fired about 1,300 additional employees at the Interior Department over the holiday weekend, according to two people familiar with the matter, adding to the widespread purge of thousands of federal workers with probationary status that began last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Delta Crash Adds to Snow Disruptions at Toronto Airport
description: Two major storms had blanketed the region for days, causing flight delays and cancellations. Two of Pearson airport’s five runways remained closed after the crash.
content: The crash of a Delta Air Lines jet on Monday afternoon exacerbated travel disruptions at Toronto Pearson International Airport, which was already juggling a slew of flight delays and cancellations caused by major back-to-back snowstorms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Hear How a ‘Smash’ Song Got a Broadway Makeover
description: “Let Me Be Your Star,” which evokes an actor’s longing to shine, has come a long way from its TV days. Here’s how the song evolved on its way to the stage.
content: On a recent morning at a rehearsal room on 42nd Street, the actress Robyn Hurder stood atop a pedestal, red lips parted, arms outstretched, blond curls vibrating as she sang the final notes of “Let Me Be Your Star.” Then she collapsed, breathless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Large Fire Erupts at Industrial Complex in Pennsylvania, Closing Schools
description: The building was evacuated and nobody was injured, the police said, but heavy smoke and the possibility of burning chemicals led officials to close local schools.
content: A large fire broke out at a manufacturing site for aviation products in Pennsylvania on Monday night, engulfing the building in flames and closing nearby schools over fears of hazardous air pollution, according to officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Judge Sets Wednesday Court Hearing to Weigh Dropping Eric Adams Case
description: Judge Dale E. Ho will hear the government’s rationale for its request to stop the corruption case against New York’s mayor. Former U.S. attorneys are asking him to investigate.
content: Judge Dale E. Ho, who on Wednesday will hold a hearing in the foundering corruption case against Mayor Eric Adams of New York, is facing a storm of demands that he look deeply into the federal government’s reasons for seeking to drop the prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams, Ana Swanson, Mary Wilson, Michael Simon Johnson, Lisa Chow, Larissa Anderson, Susan Lee, Pat McCusker, Diane Wong, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: A Conversation With the Architect of Trump’s New Trade War
description: How the president’s trade adviser rose to power.
content: During less than a month in office, President Trump has pursued more trade actions against adversaries and allies than all the trade measures he took in his entire first four-year term. There is one man guiding it all: his trade adviser Peter Navarro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Kansas Lawmakers Override Veto of Ban on Transition Care for Minors
description: Gov. Laura Kelly, a Democrat, had vetoed the bill, but the Republican-controlled Legislature overwhelmingly supported it, following the lead of other conservative states.
content: The Republican-controlled Kansas Legislature on Tuesday overrode the Democratic governor’s veto of a bill that bans gender-transition treatments for minors, fulfilling a longtime goal of conservative lawmakers and joining about half of the country’s states in enacting bans or sharp limits on those procedures.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Vance in Munich, Lecturing Europe
description: Readers respond to the vice president’s speech criticizing Europe. Also: Funding freezes; third term talk; a brave patriot; a heartsick American.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Yrjo Kukkapuro, Made Chairs Most Every Finn Has Sat On, Dies at 91
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 18, 2025.
content: “I feel like an egg yolk floating in an egg.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Bannon Calls Musk a ‘Parasitic Illegal Immigrant’
description: Stephen Bannon, a top adviser during President Trump’s first term and a popular figure among his supporters, said Elon Musk wants to “play-act as God” as part of his push to overhaul the federal government.
content: Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump’s former White House chief strategist, has renewed his feud with Elon Musk, the richest man in the world and a top Trump adviser, calling him a “parasitic illegal immigrant” in an interview published online on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Barrie Kosky Is the Director New York Has Been Waiting For
description: One of the busiest stage directors in Europe is fully arriving, at last, with “The Threepenny Opera” this spring.
content: When “The Threepenny Opera” returns to New York this spring, for an all-too-brief visit to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it will be notable for a few reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: After Walking a Fine Line With Trump, Zelensky Shows His Annoyance
description: Left out of a meeting between American and Saudi officials, the Ukrainian leader also canceled a trip to Riyadh.
content: Shortly after the United States’ opening meeting with Russian officials on Tuesday, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine lashed out at the Trump administration’s negotiating tactics in his harshest terms yet for excluding Ukrainians from talks on their own country’s fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Disagreement on Tariffs
description: We explain two competing views.
content: With many of President Trump’s policies, he and his critics agree about the likely effects even if they sharply disagree about the wisdom of those effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: New York Pays $206 Million to Settle Misconduct Suits, the Most Since 2018
description: The city spent the funds last year to settle misconduct cases involving police officers and prosecutors, according to the Legal Aid Society.
content: New York City paid out $206 million last year to settle cases involving police and prosecutorial misconduct, including decades-old wrongful convictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Fackler and Chang W. Lee
title: U.S. Marines Start to Leave Japan, Decades Behind Schedule
description: The American base on Okinawa has relocated 105 Marines. But an agreement to move 9,000 in total is colliding with the perceived threat from a rising China.
content: Before Christmas, a contingent of 105 U.S. Marines who would have been sent to Okinawa were redirected to a new base on the United States territory of Guam instead. The small reshuffling marked a major milestone: This was the first time the Marines cut their head count on Okinawa as part of a deal between Washington and Tokyo to shrink an oversized American military presence on the Pacific island that dates back to World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Dickson Despommier, Who Championed Farming in Skyscrapers, Dies at 84
description: A microbiologist, he popularized “vertical farming” — raising crops in tall buildings — to remediate climate change and feed more people.
content: Dickson Despommier, a microbiologist who proposed that cities should grow food in high-rises, popularizing the term “vertical farming” — an idea that crossed over from the realm of the purely fanciful to become a reality around the globe — died on Feb. 7 in Manhattan. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Wowed by a Loft in Philadelphia, and Its Hollywood Pedigree
description: A couple loved that their apartment was used as a location for the movie ‘Philadelphia.’ But a decade after moving in, they needed to add a new scene.
content: In 2011, when Sam Mink and Anthony Padilla bought the loft where characters played by Tom Hanks and Antonio Banderas had lived in the 1993 movie “Philadelphia,” there were many things they liked about the space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley
title: 9 Songs That Define R&B’s New Era
description: A playlist of recent tracks by women singer-songwriters, from Jazmine Sullivan to Raye, who are changing the music industry.
content: In my article on the renaissance of women in R&B, I write about a new generation of artists who are reshaping the genre, with some returning to the music’s gospel-based roots and others annexing fresh sonic territory — hybridizing with the latest hip-hop, grafting in global sounds and claiming R&B’s rightful stake in pop music today. That tells only part of the story, though, as many R&B artists resist the industry’s categorizations: While accepting the award for best country album at this year’s Grammys, Beyoncé, a 16-time winner as a solo artist in R&B categories, voiced an opinion shared by many Black artists: “I think sometimes ‘genre’ is a code word to keep us in our place.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sunil S. Amrith
title: War Has Become a Force of Planetary Destruction
description: In pursuit of empire and domination, of territorial conquest or racial and religious supremacy, wars stand as a stubborn driver of planetary harm.
content: The unrelenting Russian war has poisoned the soil, air and waters of Ukraine. Leaking ruins of chemical factories and exploded debris litter the landscape. Fires have burned across thousands of square miles, visible from space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Meghan Reimagines Her Lifestyle Brand, Calling It As Ever
description: In an Instagram video posted ahead of her upcoming Netflix series, the Duchess of Sussex announced her brand’s new name and its revamped focus.
content: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, has announced that her cooking and lifestyle brand will now be called As Ever, and she has promised there will be jam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: A Lonely Holdout Where Republicans Still Resist Trump: Utah
description: Bolstered by Mormon voters’ distaste for MAGA politics, the center-right is trying to reassert itself in a ruby-red state.
content: A new political-action committee formed by a Republican is endorsing candidates who emphasize problem solving over partisanship. A former Republican governor is trying to root out political trash talk. And a push to redraw a congressional map that could bring back a Democratic House district has been buoyed by a Republican-dominated state Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Will That Asteroid Strike Earth? Risk Level Rises to Highest Ever Recorded.
description: The threat from space rock 2024 YR4 has surpassed that of Apophis, an asteroid feared by scientists 20 years ago. The danger remains low, but experts are estimating the damage that could be done.
content: Astronomers on Tuesday said that the asteroid designated 2024 YR4 had become the most likely sizable space rock ever forecast to impact planet Earth. The object, first detected in December, is 130 to 300 feet long and expected to make a very close pass of the planet in 2032. Its odds of impacting Earth on Dec. 22 of that year currently stand at 3.1 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: An Abortion Scene Gets Theater Audiences Talking, and Fainting
description: “The Years,” running in London, dramatizes a woman’s life from teenage thrills to later-life sex. One intense scene is causing audience members to pass out.
content: About 40 minutes into a recent performance of “The Years” in London, Stephanie Schwartz suddenly felt ill and had to put her head between her legs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Donner
title: She Gathered Evidence of War Crimes. Then She Became a Victim of One.
description: The Ukrainian writer Victoria Amelina compiled stories of women resisting the Russian invasion. After she was killed, colleagues ensured publication of her unfinished book.
content: Three years after Vladimir Putin launched a large-scale invasion of Ukraine, the war is still raging. Whether Ukraine will prevail remains, for the moment, unknowable. In the bracing introductory pages of her remarkable book, “Looking at Women Looking at War,” the Ukrainian writer Victoria Amelina acknowledges the possibility of her homeland’s defeat, quoting a passage from a letter she sent to a prominent Ukrainian human rights activist: “If we lose, I want to at least tell the story of our pursuit of justice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: aerodynamics
description: This word has appeared in 29 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word aerodynamics has appeared in 29 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 9 in “The Flying Maestro: A Top Conductor Moonlights as an Air France Pilot,” an article about the conductor Daniel Harding, by Javier C. Hernández:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Amid Crashes, What Passengers Should Know About Airplane Safety
description: A spate of airplane crashes has raised travelers’ anxieties about flying. Experts say aviation remains comparatively less risky than other forms of transport and offer tips for staying safer.
content: A deadly midair collision involving a commercial airplane and an army helicopter. Multiple crashes in various countries. Planes catching on fire and even flipping upside down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner
title: Trump’s Rift With Europe Adds Fuel to a Rally in Defense Stocks
description: A flurry of trading has helped push the Pan-European Stoxx 600 index to a record high as investors expect Europe’s governments to increase military spending.
content: European defense stocks continued their rally on Tuesday, as President Trump’s threats to reduce American military support to the continent and NATO raised the prospect that Europe’s governments will increase military spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Sudanese Paramilitaries Announce Plan for Breakaway Government
description: Amid reports of new atrocities by their troops in Sudan, leaders of the Rapid Support Forces were cheered at an elaborate political event in Kenya.
content: The Rapid Support Forces, the paramilitary group battling for power in Sudan’s ruinous civil war, took a step toward forming its own breakaway government on Tuesday when it hosted a lavish political event in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Talks about Ukraine’s future.
content: European leaders convened in Paris yesterday to discuss a coordinated response as the Trump administration prepared to start its own talks with Russia about ending the war in Ukraine. The leaders were also expected to discuss military spending and how to guarantee Ukraine’s security if a permanent cease-fire or a peace deal is reached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: What to Know About Leonard Peltier, Activist Released From Prison by Biden
description: Mr. Peltier’s murder conviction and two life sentences, stemming from a 1975 shootout with F.B.I. agents on a reservation, have been widely criticized.
content: Leonard Peltier, a Native American rights activist, left federal prison in Central Florida Tuesday morning after nearly 50 years behind bars, in a victory for supporters who have criticized his prosecution as unjust and campaigned for his release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Setser
title: Xi Is Making the World Pay for China’s Mistakes
description: Trump’s tariffs are bad enough, but Xi is fundamentally distorting world trade to dig China out of the hole its economic decisions have created.
content: President Trump’s readiness to use coercive tariffs presents a profound threat to the postwar economic and political order, introducing an unpredictability to global commerce that makes it difficult for trade partners to know how to react — and next to impossible for businesses to plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Senate Confirms Howard Lutnick as Commerce Secretary
description: A longtime Wall Street executive, Mr. Lutnick will take on a broad portfolio that includes defending U.S. business interests and overseeing restrictions on technology exports.
content: The Senate on Tuesday voted 51 to 45 to confirm Howard Lutnick to be President Trump’s commerce secretary, putting in place one of the administration’s top economic officials who will help oversee an agenda around tariffs and protectionism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Harlem Ice Skaters Need Home Ice
description: The girls who participate in Figure Skating in Harlem have to travel to practice at an outdoor rink.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about a figure skating group in Harlem that is shopping for a rink. We’ll also get details on the continuing drama around Mayor Eric Adams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Prison Boss Elevated by Hochul Was Accused of Rape by 2 Former Inmates
description: The attacks occurred years earlier when Bennie Thorpe worked at a state women’s prison, his accusers said. Now he runs a prison where an inmate was fatally beaten by guards.
content: After guards at the Marcy Correctional Facility in central New York beat a handcuffed prisoner to death late last year, Gov. Kathy Hochul promised immediate reforms to turn the troubled prison around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Smartly Dressed Travelers With a Sentimental Satchel
description: Vacationers’ polished attire evoked the glamour of early jet-age travel.
content: The word “timeless” came to mind when I glimpsed Gilang Al Ghifari Lukman, left, and Medina Janneta El-Rahman at a ferry landing in Istanbul while I was in the city on vacation last November. Though it has been months since we met, I thought of them as I prepared to go to Europe for fashion shows this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor, Ian Austen and Tiffany May
title: Passengers in Toronto Recount the Moments the Plane Crashed
description: All 80 people on board are expected to survive. Two described finding themselves upside down after what had seemed like a routine descent.
content: All 80 passengers and crew members on board the Delta Air Lines flight from Minneapolis that crashed and flipped over at Toronto’s airport are expected to survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy Edelberg and Ben Harris
title: We Are Blundering Our Way Into a Financial Crisis
description: A blowup will be sparked not by government spending but from political malpractice.
content: You’ve heard warnings for years about how a fiscal crisis was brewing in the United States because the debt is unsustainable — and financial markets would eventually protest. However, the logic was often vague and the risk hypothetical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Family Files Claims Against U.S. for Washington Plane Crash
description: The filings over the collision of an American Airlines plane and an Army helicopter last month appear to be the first such claim and signal the start of a long legal fight.
content: The family of one of the 67 victims of a plane crash last month near Washington filed two legal claims against the federal government on Tuesday, seeking compensation and signifying the beginning of what is expected to be a long and complex legal fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Hundreds of Artists Call on N.E.A. to Roll Back Trump’s Restrictions
description: A letter signed by 463 playwrights, poets, dancers, visual artists and others pushes back against new grant requirements that bar the promotion of diversity or “gender ideology.”
content: In one of the first signs of collective pushback to the Trump administration’s arts initiatives, several hundred American artists are calling on the National Endowment for the Arts to roll back restrictions on grants to institutions with programming that promotes diversity or “gender ideology.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Native American Activist Leonard Peltier Released From Prison
description: Mr. Peltier was convicted in the killing of two F.B.I. agents. An order from former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will allow him to serve his remaining time under home confinement.
content: Leonard Peltier, a Native American rights activist held for nearly half a century for the killing of two F.B.I. agents, was released from a federal prison in Central Florida on Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Take it Easy
description: Erik Agard extends his regards.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Andrew Duehren and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Top Social Security Official Leaves After Musk Team Seeks Data Access
description: The departure of the acting commissioner is the latest backlash to the Department of Government Efficiency’s efforts to access sensitive data.
content: The top official at the Social Security Administration stepped down this weekend after members of Elon Musk’s so-called Department of Government Efficiency sought access to sensitive personal data about millions of Americans held by the agency, according to people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Who Runs Elon Musk’s DOGE? Not Musk, the White House Says.
description: A White House official declared that Mr. Musk was not the administrator of the so-called Department of Government Efficiency. So who is?
content: Who, exactly, runs the so-called Department of Government Efficiency?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and Hamed Aleaziz
title: Plane Flips Over in Toronto, and Migrants Trapped in Panama Hotel
description: Plus, meat raffles: like bingo, but with beef.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart Miller
title: With ‘We Beat the Dream Team,’ Grant Hill Can Finally Gloat
description: Hill and the film’s director talked about the time a team of college basketball players beat Michael Jordan, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson — and the effort to bury it.
content: Grant Hill is a seven-time N.B.A. All-Star, Chris Webber a five-timer and Penny Hardaway a four-timer. Allan Houston was selected twice, Jamal Mashburn once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Whitfield
title: Does the Art World Need a New Avant-Garde to Shake It Up?
description: A new book by Morgan Falconer argues that artists working today should take inspiration from Futurism, Dada and other art movements that sought to reinvent the field.
content: In July 1915, on the shores of Lake Garda, Filippo Tommaso Marinetti mounted his army-issue bicycle to perform military drills alongside the rest of the Lombard Battalion of Volunteer Cyclists and Motorists. In the hot Italian sun they raced their bicycles up hills under an enemy bombardment simulated by “a hail of vegetables.” Six years earlier, Marinetti had published the Futurist Manifesto, declaring, “We intend to sing the love of danger, the habit of energy and fearlessness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Fackler and Kiuko Notoya
title: Okinawa, a Small Island Caught Between Big Powers
description: Residents of the Japanese island see U.S. bases as a legacy of war and colonialism, but younger generations also worry about a threat from China.
content: Keiko Itokazu can still remember the day in 1965 when the parachute didn’t open. It was attached to a jeep trailer that was dropped from an airplane, along with U.S. paratroopers training near her home in Okinawa. The plummeting object missed her but hit a nearby house, killing a fifth-grade schoolgirl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Karoun Demirjian
title: In Trump’s War on Foreign Aid, a Loyal Soldier Returns to Battle
description: A meeting between a Hungarian official and Pete Marocco, the top Trump appointee in charge of foreign aid, signals a new future.
content: Pete Marocco has spent much of this month hunkered in an office suite on the seventh floor of the State Department overseeing the dismantling of the architecture for how the United States delivers foreign aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Jane Fonda, Sneakerhead
description: The actor and activist on aging into her latest role: sneaker model.
content: The activity that Jane Fonda, the 87-year-old Oscar winner, activist and aerobics queen, is most associated with these days is probably environmental protest (well, that, the “Grace and Frankie” series and the “Book Club” film franchise). She did, after all, move to Washington, D.C., in 2019 specifically to draw attention to the climate crisis, getting arrested pretty much every Friday while staging sit-ins at the Capitol. Then she swore off buying new clothes, even for the red carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays, Maria Cramer and William K. Rashbaum
title: Adams Taps Close Associate for Top Public Safety Job
description: The deputy police commissioner, Kaz Daughtry, replaces Chauncey Parker, a veteran prosecutor and law enforcement administrator who announced his resignation amid City Hall turmoil.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York has chosen Kaz Daughtry, a deputy police commissioner known for his combative social media presence and close relationship with the mayor, to be deputy mayor for public safety, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Do Women Need More Sleep Than Men?
description: We asked experts the question that’s all over our social media feeds.
content: Q: I’ve heard that women need several hours more sleep per night than men do. Is this true?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Madison Malone Kircher
title: Can This Fish Make You Cry?
description: An eerie looking creature from the ocean’s depths has become an unwitting inspiration for intense emotions.
content: It is easy to believe that the black seadevil anglerfish, with its gaping maw of razor-like teeth, a bioluminescent rod sticking out of its head and lidless eyes used to scan the deepest, darkest depths of the ocean, might make someone cry with fright.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Carington
title: London’s Most Despised Thoroughfare Is Actually Kind of Great
description: Euston Road hosts the site of the longest Champagne bar in Europe, five Pret-a-Mangers and a phenomenal E.R. that I recommend to anyone considering breaking a bone.
content: Euston Road isn’t the kind of place Londoners go on purpose. It’s a wretched six-lane thoroughfare between King’s Cross and Great Portland Street, high both in levels of air pollution and in the number of people in a traffic-induced tizz. It’s a place you suffer through on your way to somewhere more pleasant. “Meet you on Euston Road!” said nobody, ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol C. Lam
title: Farewell, Justice Department Independence
description: I was ousted as a U.S. attorney for political reasons. The lessons we learned have been discarded.
content: Over just a few days last week, the Trump administration made a laughingstock of the U.S. Department of Justice. The department’s decision to seek the dismissal of a corruption indictment against Mayor Eric Adams of New York led seven prosecutors handling the case to resign in disgust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Climate Aid Projects Fighting Extremism and Unrest Are Closing Down
description: Heat, drought and floods are growing security risks, Western defense officials say, feeding instability and violence that could prove costly in the long term.
content: Numerous programs aimed at averting violence, instability and extremism worsened by global warming are ensnared in the effort to dismantle the main American aid agency, U.S.A.I.D.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis, Hospitalized, Has Pneumonia, Vatican Says
description: The Vatican said that the pontiff had pneumonia in both lungs and that he “continued to present a complex picture.”
content: Pope Francis has developed pneumonia in both lungs and will not participate in activities through the weekend because of his health issues, the Vatican announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 18, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2025.
content: An article on Sunday about the rise in thefts of popular weight-loss drugs in Brazil misstated the name of a company that owns a chain of pharmacies in the country. It is Grupo DPSP, not Grupo DPS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: A Democrat Who Is Thinking Differently
description: Representative Jake Auchincloss discusses how the Democratic Party can offer meaningful alternatives to voters.
content: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump May Name a Woman He Once Pardoned to Be His ‘Pardon Czar’
description: Alice Marie Johnson was serving a life sentence for a nonviolent drug conviction when the president commuted her sentence in 2018. Since then, she has become a criminal justice reform activist.
content: President Trump’s advisers are considering Alice Marie Johnson, who was serving a life sentence for a drug conviction when the president commuted her sentence during his first term, to be the “pardon czar,” according to three people familiar with the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes
title: Court Rules Against Cuomo’s Attempt to Dismantle State Ethics Panel
description: New York’s highest court rejected the former governor’s push to undermine an ethics commission that had been investigating a $5.1 million book deal he received for a memoir.
content: New York’s highest court on Tuesday rejected efforts by former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to dismantle a state ethics commission that had been investigating a $5.1 million book deal he had received, ruling that the body’s creation was constitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: As Deadline for Withdrawal Passes, Israel Remains in Parts of Southern Lebanon
description: Israeli forces pulled out of populated areas in southern Lebanon, but retained control over strategic border points as a deadline lapsed for both Israel and Hezbollah to leave the region.
content: Israel pulled its troops from towns and villages in southern Lebanon on Tuesday, according to the United Nations, but held onto strategic positions along the border as a deadline elapsed for both Israel and Hezbollah to fully withdraw from the south.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Gil Won-ok, Crusading Victim of Wartime Sex Slavery, Dies at 96
description: She campaigned for a formal apology and reparations from Japan for what it did to thousands of women like her, mostly Korean, during World War II.
content: Gil Won-ok, one of the last survivors of sexual slavery for Japan’s World War II troops, who campaigned to bring international attention to the suffering of thousands of women like her​, died on Sunday at her home in Incheon, South Korea, west of Seoul. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Bumiller
title: Trump’s Revenge Now Includes His Takeover of the Kennedy Center
description: What will a thin-skinned showman do with an institution central to Washington’s cultural life? One expectation is more country music.
content: The trouble started in August 2017 when the television producer Norman Lear said he was skipping a White House reception for his Kennedy Center Honors award. Another honoree, the dancer and choreographer Carmen de Lavallade, pulled out after President Trump said there were “very fine people on both sides” of a white supremacist rally and counterprotest in Charlottesville, Va.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harold Goldberg
title: Riot Grrrl Rebellion With Supernatural Cues
description: The opener of the episodic game Lost Records: Bloom & Rage inspires and intrigues.
content: The narratively profuse mystery game Lost Records: Bloom & Rage is like living in a Bikini Kill song followed by a Phoebe Bridgers ballad. The four main characters who form the title band, Bloom and Rage, are strong together — even as teenagers, even when one describes herself as meek. Through the highs of anger and the depths of sadness, they search for deeper meaning through self-discovery as they come of age. It’s freeing. It’s feminist. It’s powerful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Alexander Brothers Face More Lawsuits Accusing Them of Sexual Assault
description: Tal Alexander and Oren Alexander, once top real estate brokers, and their brother Alon Alexander are currently in jail awaiting trial on federal sex-trafficking charges.
content: Eleven more women have filed lawsuits against one or more of the Alexander brothers, the once high-flying trio who are facing multiple accusations of sexual assault in both civil and criminal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,341
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Feb. 19, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar and Vidhya Nagarajan
title: At Luna Luna You Can Look, but Please Don’t Hop on the Rides
description: Visitors to the carnival, at the Shed through March 16, have been mostly undeterred by the Basquiat Ferris wheel and other attractions being off limits. It “makes it more mystical,” one guest said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Roasted Chicken Thighs With Hot Honey and Lime: Dinner in No Time
description: Speedy and simple to make; spectacular to eat.
content: My favorite recipes to cook at home aren’t the showiest or the most elaborate. They’re the simple ones that have something I think of as a “lightbulb moment” — an idea, technique or ingredient that makes a dish distinctive, maybe even brilliant. You know a recipe has a lightbulb moment when you make it and you can’t get over how good it is, how excellent its ratio of effort to flavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ismaeel Naar
title: U.S. and Russia Pursue Partnership in a Head-Spinning Shift in Relations
description: The two sides met in Saudi Arabia for their most extensive discussions in years. In addition to Ukraine, business ties were on the table.
content: The United States and Russia moved toward a head-spinning reset of their relationship on Tuesday, agreeing to work together on ending the Ukraine war, financial investment and re-establishing normal relations. The meeting between senior officials from both countries was a striking display of bonhomie after three years of American efforts to isolate Moscow for its 2022 invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: The Gene That Made Mice Squeak Strangely
description: A new study suggests that the NOVA1 gene may have been a key player in the evolution of human language.
content: Scientists have long struggled to understand how human language evolved. Words and sentences don’t leave fossils behind for paleontologists to dig up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Wednesday Briefing: U.S. and Russia Discuss Cooperation
description: Plus, the women leading R&B’s new wave.
content: Senior U.S. and Russian officials agreed yesterday not only to work together on ending the war in Ukraine, but also to cooperate on financial investment and re-establishing normal relations. The negotiations were the most extensive in years between the two global powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Answering Life’s Health Questions, One Week at a Time
description: Why am I so tired? Can alcohol cause panic attacks? In Ask Well, a column edited by Julia Calderone, The Times tackles readers’ personal health questions.
content: There are certain questions in life — about relationships, work or health — that can feel too intimate to ask even a friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Fatima AbdulKarim
title: Hamas Says Remains of Israeli Captives, Including Bibas Family, Will Be Handed Over on Thursday
description: The militant group’s chief negotiator also said Hamas would increase the number of living hostages it would release on Saturday to six from three.
content: Khalil al-Hayya, Hamas’s chief negotiator, said in a speech on Tuesday that militants intended to hand over the remains of four Israeli hostages to Israel on Thursday in exchange for the release of Palestinian prisoners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Qasim Nauman
title: String of Air Crashes in 2025 Has Rattled Travelers
description: The accidents, which remain under investigation, have prompted criticism of U.S. aviation regulators.
content: The Delta Air Lines crash at Toronto Pearson International Airport on Monday is the latest in a series of accidents this year that has spread anxiety among air travelers and prompted sharp criticism of American aviation regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: OpenAI’s Former Chief Technology Officer Starts Her Own Company
description: Mira Murati, who left OpenAI last year, has helped establish Thinking Machines Lab, a new artificial intelligence start-up.
content: Mira Murati, the former chief technology officer of OpenAI who unexpectedly left the company in September, has helped found a new artificial intelligence start-up called Thinking Machines Lab, adding to the wave of young companies that have been formed in the race to lead A.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Would You Ever Give Up Your Smartphone?
description: There’s a growing movement at high schools and colleges that promotes conscious consumption of technology, especially social media. Would you consider joining?
content: Do you own a smartphone? If you do, would you ever consider trading it in for a flip phone, or a phone that only allows you to make calls and send texts? Would you consider giving your phone up altogether?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Europe’s Leaders, Dazed by an Ally Acting Like an Adversary, Recalculate
description: Faced with undisguised hostility from the Trump administration, Europeans are preparing for what is shaping up to be a go-it-alone era.
content: For years, European leaders have fretted about reducing their dependence on a wayward United States. On Monday, at a hastily arranged meeting in Paris, the hand-wringing gave way to harried acceptance of a new world in which Europe’s most powerful ally has begun acting more like an adversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Judge Declines to Block Musk Team’s Foray Into Federal Agencies
description: A coalition of states had sought to temporarily block Elon Musk’s operatives from having access to sensitive data and ordering mass firings.
content: A federal judge in Washington gave President Trump a victory for now when she declined on Tuesday to bar Elon Musk and his associates from ordering mass firings or having access to data at seven federal agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Neil Vigdor
title: What We Know About the Toronto Plane Crash
description: All 80 people aboard the Delta flight from Minneapolis clambered out of the plane, with 18 suffering injuries.
content: A Delta Air Lines passenger jet made a dramatic crash landing at Toronto Pearson International Airport on Monday afternoon, flipping upside down on the tarmac with its tail and one wing shorn off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jehan Alladina, C. Corey Hardin and Alexander Rabin
title: Censored Science Can’t Save Lives
description: Progress cannot occur if scientists are barred from asking certain questions.
content: In our careers as pulmonary and critical-care doctors, we have witnessed a revolution in treating asthma, a disease that affects one in 12 Americans. Newer medications make it possible to reverse the course of the disease and bring people with severe asthma into remission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Llama San Team Expands Nikkei Cooking at Papa San
description: Gui Steakhouse serves chops and Sichuan sides, Le Petit Village brings more French to the West Village and more news.
content: Nikkei, the fusion of Japanese and Peruvian cuisines that is a hallmark of Peru, again inspires Juan Correa and Erik Ramirez of Llama San, who also own Llama Inn. Looking to the Japanese izakaya for style, they’re serving ceviches, makis, tiraditos, zensai, robata grill items and donburi. There’s also a chicken tour de force, with the entire bird deconstructed from beak to tail with yakitori style gizzards, heart, wings, crisp skin, chicken sausage and broth. Their Nikkei also crosses paths with other cuisines in cacio e pepe udon, unagi pizza and yuzu Béarnaise. Neon accents add color to the generously windowed industrial space with a stretch of open kitchen and a mezzanine bar. Consultants from Tres Monos, a notable Buenos Aires bar, helped shape the cocktail menu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Why Did the Seal Cross the Road? To Get to Connecticut’s Pizza Haven.
description: The police in New Haven, Conn., found a young seal wandering the streets and aided in its rescue. “Maybe we should just start keeping mackerel in the cruisers,” one officer suggested.
content: It was an unusual 911 call on a Sunday afternoon in New Haven, Conn. At about 2:30 p.m., in a neighborhood full of auto shops, an IKEA and renowned pizzerias, someone reported that a seal was “running back and forth” near a bridge underpass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: $67 a Day for a Week of Skiing? We Put the Indy Pass to the Test.
description: Our Frugal Traveler tries out the bargain pass at frill-free resorts in Utah, Idaho and Montana.
content: In January, my family and I arrived at Pomerelle Mountain Resort in southern Idaho to find fresh powder, inexpensive lift tickets, no lines and bargain burgers grilling at the base. What more could a skier ask for?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Elon Musk Is Leading a ‘Hostile Takeover of the Federal Government’
description: His mandate under Trump “truly is unprecedented in U.S. history.”
content: President Trump has empowered Elon Musk, one of the richest men in the world, to fire government employees, eliminate federal agencies and run roughshod over both federal law and the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: A Soundtrack to a Fabulous Memoir Crackling With Music
description: Hear songs from Lucy Sante’s “I Heard Her Call My Name” by ESG Public Image Ltd., the Floaters and more.
content: I read a lot of books about music. When I’m really enjoying one, sometimes I’ll make a playlist of songs mentioned in its pages to stave off that bittersweet feeling that always comes upon finishing a satisfying read. That way, I can always crawl back into a book’s atmosphere just by pressing play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Eakin
title: A Story of Love, Critical Theory and Other Wild Fictions
description: In Michelle de Kretser’s new novel, a young graduate student gets caught in the gap between ideals and real life.
content: In the 1980s, an intellectual revolution took hold on college campuses, spreading, this newspaper reported at the time, “like kudzu.” Under the deceptively unassuming shorthand of “theory,” a heady brew of philosophical schools and ideas — many of them imported from France — upended longstanding assumptions about language, meaning, reality and the human self. According to theory, words referred not to the world they were tasked with representing but only to other words in a ruthless system where meaning was elusive, reality an illusion and the self a romantic fiction perpetrated by the capitalist bourgeoisie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: As a G.O.P. Congressman Takes Aim at Hochul, a Democrat Eyes His Seat
description: Representative Mike Lawler, Republican of New York, is contemplating running for governor next year. Beth Davidson, a Democrat, hopes to win his swing seat in the Hudson Valley.
content: As he contemplates a run for governor next year, Representative Mike Lawler of New York was already sparring with one potential Democratic opponent, Gov. Kathy Hochul. Now, he is getting one for his current seat, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie-Helene Bertino
title: He’s Dead. His Ghost Isn’t the Only Thing Haunting His Girlfriend.
description: In Evie Wyld’s new novel, “The Echoes,” a woman mourns her partner while also contending with the traumatic past she left behind.
content: Death and its ambassadors, ghosts, are perpetually in style. Lookit: Just yesterday, in fact, several people died. Already this year, two movies on the topic have premiered: a remastering of Michael Roemer’s brilliant 1976 cinéma vérité film “Dying,” and “Presence,” Steven Soderbergh’s paranormal thriller about a ghost haunting the new home of a seemingly typical family. Both reminded me of Max, the charming ghost protagonist of “The Echoes,” Evie Wyld’s fourth novel. I’m not spoiling anything by revealing his death: Max is dead in the first sentence of the book. But he has not been allowed to move on, or even leave his London flat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Hochul Meets With City Leaders to Discuss the ‘Path Forward’ for Mayor
description: After four top aides to Mayor Eric Adams resigned, calls for him to step down are growing.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul raised the prospect of removing Mayor Eric Adams from office late Monday and met with “key leaders” in Manhattan on Tuesday to discuss “the path forward, with the goal of ensuring stability for the City of New York.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Find the 13 Book Titles Hidden in This Text Puzzle?
description: Certain books maintain an evergreen popularity long after they have been published. See if you can uncover the baker’s dozen of 20th-century classics concealed in this short scene — and build a reading list along the way.
content: Certain books maintain an evergreen popularity long after they have been published. See if you can uncover the baker’s dozen of 20th-century classics concealed in this short scene — and build a reading list along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney and Harry Stevens
title: A Slow-Moving California Landslide Suddenly Speeds Up
description: A new map shows where land movement is accelerating, buckling roads and collapsing homes.
content: A new map shows where land movement is accelerating, buckling roads and collapsing homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Lovallo
title: My Favorite Song | R&B’s New Guard
description: H.E.R., Coco Jones, Victoria Monét and Muni Long pay tribute to the women singer-songwriters of the 1990s and early 2000s.
content: H.E.R., Coco Jones, Victoria Monét and Muni Long pay tribute to the women singer-songwriters of the 1990s and early 2000s.
